days_plan.itin_title: Wisconsin's Great Drives: Door County, Apostle Islands & Driftless Area

visits.text: Hot Springs National Park - America's Original Spa Since 1832: The nation's oldest protected natural area surrounds 47 thermal springs pushing 143°F waters through ancient Ouachita rock. Bathhouse Row's eight stunning structures span Spanish Colonial to Art Deco styles, with the Fordyce Bathhouse now serving as the park's opulent visitor center showcasing gilded age bathing culture.

Hot Springs Mountain Tower - 360° Views from 1,256 Feet Above Sea Level: This 216-foot observation tower crowns the thermal mountain, offering panoramic vistas across the Ouachita Mountain range. On exceptional days, visibility reaches 140 miles to the Ozark Plateau.

Bathhouse Row - The Most Elegant Mile in Arkansas: Eight magnificent bathhouses line Central Avenue, each an architectural masterpiece from the thermal bathing industry's golden era. Two remain operational, offering traditional soaking experiences in waters that have drawn wellness seekers since prehistoric times.

activities.text: Traditional Thermal Bathing - Soak in Earth's Ancient Heat: Experience the therapeutic tradition that attracted Al Capone, Babe Ruth, and presidents to these naturally heated mineral waters, flowing continuously for over 4,000 years from deep within the Ouachita Mountains.

days_plan.itin_title: Arkansas Itinerary: Hot Springs, Ozarks and Natural Parks

visits.text: Jean Lafitte National Historical Park — Explore the Barataria Preserve's 9,200 hectares of bayous, swamps, and marshes representing Mississippi River delta ecosystems. Boardwalk trails wind through cypress-tupelo swamps inhabited by alligators and wading birds.

Southdown Plantation House — Tour this 1858 Greek Revival mansion converted into a museum documenting terrebonne Parish's sugar industry and Mardi Gras traditions. The house features original furnishings, Mardi Gras costumes, and local history exhibits.

Wetlands Acadian Cultural Center — Learn about Cajun, Native American, and African American cultures shaping Louisiana's coastal wetlands. Exhibits explain how communities adapted to living in America's most extensive coastal marsh system.

Mandalay National Wildlife Refuge — Drive or boat through 17,500 hectares protecting coastal marsh habitat for wintering waterfowl and resident alligators. The refuge demonstrates coastal erosion challenges threatening Louisiana's disappearing wetlands.

activities.text: Airboat swamp tour — Skim across shallow marshes and bayous at high speed spotting alligators, nutria, and abundant birdlife. Local Cajun guides explain wetland ecology while navigating channels through sawgrass and water hyacinths.

Fresh Gulf seafood — Dine on boiled crawfish, fried catfish, and shrimp po-boys at waterfront restaurants serving daily catches. Terrebonne Parish fishermen supply restaurants with Gulf shrimp, oysters, and blue crabs.

Cajun music at Jolly Inn — Hear traditional Cajun musicians playing accordion, fiddle, and washboard at this authentic dance hall. The family-run venue preserves musical traditions passed through generations of South Louisiana families.

days_plan.itin_title: Louisiana Cultural Journey: New Orleans Jazz to Cajun Bayou Country

visits.text: Visit to the USS KIDD Veterans museum in Baton Rouge.
Visit to the Great River Road Museum and walk in the gardens.

days_plan.itin_title: Louisiana Soundtrack: A Cultural Tour from New Orleans Jazz to Cajun Bayous

visits.text: Visit Space Center Houston, the official visitor center of NASA's Johnson Space Center, featuring authentic spacecraft, interactive exhibits, and behind-the-scenes tram tours of actual NASA facilities including historic Mission Control. This world-class museum allows visitors to touch a real moon rock, see the massive Saturn V rocket, and learn about current and future space exploration missions. The center provides an unparalleled look at America's space program from Mercury through the International Space Station.

Explore Houston's renowned Museum District, home to 19 museums within walking distance including the Museum of Fine Arts and the Houston Museum of Natural Science. The diverse collections span art, science, history, and culture, with several museums offering free admission on designated days. The district represents one of the largest cultural concentrations in the United States, rivaling collections in much larger cities.

activities.text: Wander through the Houston Zoo and adjacent Hermann Park, where the Japanese Garden provides a peaceful retreat amid the bustling fourth-largest city in America. The Museum of Natural Science features exceptional dinosaur exhibits, a planetarium, and a butterfly center housing thousands of live butterflies. Houston's multicultural dining scene reflects its diverse population, offering exceptional cuisines from around the world.

Experience the Texas Medical Center, the largest medical complex in the world treating millions of patients annually, representing Houston's role as a global leader in healthcare and medical research. The city serves as the world energy capital with over 500 oil and energy firms headquartered in the metropolitan area. Save on major attractions including the Space Center and Zoo with a Houston CityPASS for convenient and affordable exploration.

days_plan.itin_title: Discovering Texas: Hill Country, Big Bend & Gulf Coast Beaches

visits.text: Humboldt - Small Town, Big-Thinking Revival: A devoted team of entrepreneurs has launched an effort to update this small eastern Kansas town in surprisingly innovative ways.
Base Camp Humboldt - Scandinavian-Inspired Glamping: Rental cabins perch around a large fishing pond, with bike rentals providing access to adjacent rail trails for multi-day adventures.
Southwind Rail Trail and Prairie Spirit Trail - 51+ Miles of Trail Adventures: These connected trails offer cycling and hiking through Kansas countryside, accessible right from Base Camp.
Humboldt Mercantile - Kansas-Made Goods and Craft Coffee: Browse a curated selection of Kansas-made products while enjoying locally roasted coffee drinks.
Water Tower Mural - Humboldt's Instagram Moment: Snap a selfie beside the colorful mural depicting the town's notable water tower proclaiming 'Life is fine in Humboldt.'

activities.text: Rail Trail Cycling - Pedal Through Eastern Kansas: Rent a bike and explore dozens of miles of converted rail corridors passing through prairie landscapes and small towns.

days_plan.itin_title: Kansas Prairie Odyssey: Tallgrass Seas, Cowtowns & Western Legends

visits.text: Jour 1: Step into humanity's greatest adventure at the US Space & Rocket Center, where towering Saturn V rockets pierce the Alabama sky and the dreams of space exploration come alive. Wander through the awe-inspiring Saturn V Hall, home to one of only three remaining moon rockets, and stand beneath the very engines that propelled astronauts to the lunar surface. Don't miss the meticulously recreated International Space Station module, where you'll discover the ingenious solutions astronauts use for everyday tasks in zero gravity.

Jour 1: Channel your inner astronaut at Space Camp, the legendary program that has inspired generations of future scientists and explorers since 1982. Whether you're traveling with curious kids or harboring your own cosmic dreams, the center offers immersive experiences from simulated shuttle missions to underwater astronaut training. The gift shop is a treasure trove of NASA memorabilia and space-themed souvenirs you won't find anywhere else.

Jour 2: Wander through the tree-lined streets of the Twickenham Historic District, where antebellum mansions draped in Southern grandeur transport you to a pre-Civil War era of cotton wealth and gracious living. This remarkable neighborhood boasts Alabama's finest concentration of historic homes, their columned porticos and wraparound verandas whispering tales of a bygone age. Pick up a self-guided walking tour from the Visitor Bureau and let the free audio guides bring each architectural treasure to life.

Jour 2: Discover artistic treasures overlooking the serene waters of Big Spring Park at the Huntsville Museum of Art, a jewel box of carefully curated collections. The haunting black-and-white photographs of the Vietnam: The Real War exhibition offer profound reflections on conflict, while the luminous landscapes of the Ponchin legacy celebrate the artistic bonds between a French father and son. Marvel at the Buccellati silver menagerie, where semi-precious stones and gleaming silver transform into lifelike creatures of extraordinary craftsmanship.

Jour 2: Find your peaceful center at Big Spring Park, Huntsville's beloved green heart where the city's founding spring still bubbles up from ancient limestone caves beneath your feet. Stroll across the graceful Japanese bridge reflected in lily-pad-dotted waters, or spread a picnic blanket on the manicured lawns where festivals and community gatherings have brought neighbors together for generations. The smaller park section features a dancing fountain fed by the original spring that drew settler John Hunt to establish his cabin here in 1805.

Jour 2: Journey back to the summer of 1819 at Alabama Constitutional Hall Park, where delegates gathered in a humble cabinetmaker's workshop to forge the state's founding document. The meticulously reconstructed wooden buildings surrounding the central courtyard paint a vivid portrait of frontier life, from the postmaster's quarters to the blacksmith's forge. Join a guided tour to peek inside furnished interiors and imagine the heated debates that shaped Alabama's destiny.

Jour 2: Browse the nostalgic aisles of Harrison Bros. Hardware, where original wooden counters, brass cash registers, and floor-to-ceiling shelves evoke the general stores of yesteryear. Though the nails and tacks have given way to locally crafted treasures and Rocket City memorabilia, the store's authentic 19th-century character remains gloriously intact. This is the place to find that perfect American-made souvenir that captures Huntsville's unique blend of history and innovation.

Jour 3: Lose yourself in 112 acres of botanical wonder at the Huntsville Botanical Garden, a volunteer-driven labor of love that has blossomed into one of the South's premier horticultural destinations. Glide through the grounds on a golf buggy tour, pausing at the Damson Aquatic Garden where a Japanese pavilion floats serenely above pools carpeted with water lilies. Time your visit for summer when the Daylily Garden erupts in a sunset palette of gold, coral, and rose that will take your breath away.

Jour 3: Watch children's imaginations take flight in the enchanting Children's Garden, where wading pools sparkle in the sun, dinosaur bones await discovery, and fairytale creatures peek from hidden corners. The butterfly house offers pure magic as kaleidoscopic wings flutter around you, landing on tropical blooms and sipping from shallow pools in a living rainbow of color.

Jour 3: Ascend Monte Sano to discover Burritt on the Mountain, the eclectic retirement retreat of homeopathic physician Dr. William Henry Burritt, who sought the cooler mountain air and woodland tranquility above the city. Tour the 1930s mansion furnished with period pieces, then wander the historic park where relocated log cabins and wooden farmhouses reveal how Alabama's pioneers lived and worked. Chat with costumed interpreters, meet the friendly farm goats, and try your hand at traditional handicrafts at the folk school.

Jour 3: Step into a creative wonderland at Lowe Mill, the South's largest independent arts facility housed in a magnificently repurposed textile mill. Over 200 working artists have transformed this industrial cathedral into a vibrant village of studios, galleries, and cafes where you can watch potters throw clay, painters layer color, and jewelers craft wearable art. Check the schedule for concerts on the dock, where musicians perform on a raised walkway while audiences picnic around the iconic water tower.

activities.text: Jour 1: Rise early and join the locals at the beloved Blue Plate Cafe for an authentic Southern breakfast that will fuel your adventures. Sink your fork into fluffy scrambled eggs alongside crispy bacon, impossibly creamy cheese grits, and the quintessential Southern duo of buttermilk biscuits smothered in rich sausage gravy. The bottomless coffee flows freely as regulars swap stories at the counter, offering a genuine taste of Huntsville hospitality.

Jour 1: As evening falls, treat yourself to refined Southern cuisine at Connors Steak & Seafood, where Gulf Coast flavors meet prime cuts in an elegant yet welcoming atmosphere. The Cajun Red Grouper, mesquite-grilled to perfection and served with fluffy couscous and tender collard greens, showcases the region's culinary heritage. Start with the legendary Voodoo Shrimp bathed in a spicy remoulade sauce that'll have you reaching for another.

Jour 2: Savor a leisurely lunch at Pane e Vino, Chef James Boyce's Italian-inspired haven with a terrace overlooking the park's shimmering waters. The handmade butternut squash ravioli, draped in sage brown butter, offers a delicate counterpoint to the hearty Southern fare you'll encounter throughout your journey. Pair it with a crisp glass of wine as you watch ducks glide across the lake.

Jour 3: Fuel your creativity at Piper and Leaf, a Lowe Mill gem specializing in artisan tea blends crafted from locally foraged ingredients and organic herbs. Sample their signature Southern sweet tea reimagined with wild honeysuckle or choose from inventive blends that capture Alabama's seasons in every sip. The whimsically decorated shop invites lingering over a steaming cup.

Jour 3: Hunt for Huntsville's vibrant street art, starting with the massive Koi mural where giant fish seem ready to gulp you whole at the intersection of Spring and Spragins Streets. Stand on the marked spot to experience the stunning 3D effect, then seek out the playful Welcome to Huntsville rocket mural facing Big Spring Park. Art enthusiasts can extend their treasure hunt along the Clinton Row Color Walk and the mysterious Downtown Secret Art Trail.

days_plan.itin_title: Alabama Deep South Itinerary: Civil Rights, Music and Gulf Coast

visits.text: Hutchinson - Where Space Race History Meets Subterranean Wonder: This central Kansas city delivers world-class attractions both above and below ground, from space exploration to salt mine adventures.

Cosmosphere - The World's Largest Combined Collection of U.S. and Russian Space Artifacts: Kansas's only Smithsonian-affiliated museum boasts flown spacecraft from the first three human-carrying space programs-Mercury, Gemini, and Apollo-relaunching the Space Race through extraordinary exhibits.

Strataca - 650 Feet Below Kansas: A 6-ton hoist drops visitors through a frozen aquifer and layers of rock to a museum carved from a former section of an active salt mine, with detailed underground exhibits explaining what secrets lie stored beneath the prairie.

Kansas State Fair - September Celebration of Sunflower State Pride: Each September, Hutchinson hosts the Kansas State Fair, celebrating all things Kansas with livestock exhibitions, carnival rides, concerts, and agricultural displays.

activities.text: Underground Salt Mine Tour - Experience a World Without Sunlight: Explore the vast chambers and corridors carved from ancient salt deposits, learning about this unusual underground world and its modern uses.

days_plan.itin_title: Kansas Prairie Odyssey: Tallgrass Seas, Cowtowns & Western Legends

visits.text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art — Explore 5,000 years of art across 2 million square feet in this encyclopedic museum founded in 1870. Highlights include the Egyptian Temple of Dendur, European Old Masters, and the American Wing's period rooms.

Vanderbilt Mansion — Tour this Gilded Age palazzo built in 1899 for Frederick Vanderbilt, grandson of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt. The 54-room Beaux-Arts mansion showcases Renaissance Revival architecture and Hudson River School landscape design across 211 acres.

FDR Presidential Library and Museum — Visit America's first presidential library opened in 1941, containing Franklin D. Roosevelt's papers and artifacts from his unprecedented four terms. The museum chronicles the New Deal, World War II, and Eleanor Roosevelt's advocacy.

Walkway Over the Hudson — Cross this 2-kilometer pedestrian bridge suspended 65 meters above the Hudson River, the world's longest elevated pedestrian bridge. Built on a former 1889 railroad bridge, it offers sweeping valley and mountain views.

activities.text: Wine tasting in Hudson Valley — Sample award-winning wines at family-owned vineyards planted in the rolling hills. Rieslings and Cabernet Francs thrive in the microclimates while tasting rooms offer farm-to-table pairings with Hudson River views.

Culinary Institute of America campus visit — Explore the world's premier culinary college founded in 1946, housed in a former Jesuit seminary. Student-run restaurants serve exceptional cuisine prepared by tomorrow's master chefs in training.

Antique shopping in Cold Spring — Browse Victorian-era storefronts along Main Street filled with vintage treasures, Hudson River School paintings, and artisan crafts. This charming village nestled below Storm King Mountain retains its 1800s character.

days_plan.itin_title: Empire State Road Trip: From Manhattan Skyscrapers to Niagara Falls

visits.text: Islamorada - The Sport Fishing Capital of the World: This stretch of islands has earned its title through legendary catches of sailfish, marlin, mahi-mahi, and tarpon that draw anglers from around the globe.
Robbie's Marina - Hand-Feed Giant Tarpon: This quirky marina has become famous for its resident tarpon, massive silver fish that leap from the water to snatch bait from visitors' hands.
Indian Key Historic State Park - A Ghost Town in the Gulf: This small island, accessible only by kayak or boat, preserves the ruins of a wrecking town destroyed by Seminoles in 1840.
Deep-sea fishing excursion in the world capital of sport fishing.
Discovery of Windley Key Fossil Reef Geological State Park and its fossilized coral formations.

activities.text: Deep Sea Fishing Charters - Battle the Big Ones: Charter boats depart daily for offshore adventures targeting the gamefish that made Islamorada famous.
Kayaking to Indian Key - Paddle to History: Launch from Robbie's Marina for a short paddle to explore overgrown foundations and the stories of frontier Florida.
Observation and feeding of tarpons at Robbie's Marina.

Florida Keys Overseas Highway: Miami to Key West Road Trip

visits.text: Taughannock Falls — Hike to this 65-meter waterfall plunging into a glacial gorge carved over 10,000 years ago. The falls exceed Niagara in single-drop height, cascading over layered Devonian shale and sandstone deposited 350 million years ago.

Cornell University — Tour this Ivy League institution founded in 1865 on East Hill overlooking Cayuga Lake. The 930-hectare campus features Gothic Revival buildings, the Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art designed by I.M. Pei, and spectacular gorge views.

Ithaca Falls — Discover this 46-meter waterfall cascading through the heart of downtown Ithaca. The easily accessible cataract flows over Devonian bedrock, creating a powerful spectacle especially during spring snowmelt or after heavy rains.

Buttermilk Falls State Park — Explore ten cascading waterfalls descending 152 meters through a narrow gorge. The Gorge Trail winds past frothing pools and mossy cliffs where Buttermilk Creek has carved intricate patterns into ancient sedimentary rock.

activities.text: Cayuga Lake wine trail — Visit family wineries along the western shore of the Finger Lakes' longest lake stretching 61 kilometers. Cool-climate Rieslings and sparkling wines benefit from the lake's moderating influence and well-drained glacial soils.

Ithaca Commons shopping — Stroll this pedestrian mall filled with independent bookstores, artisan boutiques, and farm-to-table restaurants. The outdoor plaza hosts farmers markets and live music in a vibrant college-town atmosphere.

Sunset cruise on Cayuga Lake — Glide across the tranquil waters as the sun sets behind the western hills. Evening cruises offer wine tastings while waterfowl and the occasional bald eagle provide natural entertainment.

days_plan.itin_title: Empire State Road Trip: From Manhattan Skyscrapers to Niagara Falls

visits.text: Jacksonville - Florida's Largest City by Land Area: Located 30 minutes from Georgia, this sprawling metropolis spreads across both banks of the St. Johns River, offering urban attractions alongside easy beach access.

Five Points Neighborhood - Where Hip Meets Historic: Browse antique shops, sample craft brews at local gastropubs, and experience Jacksonville's most eclectic district, where Victorian homes neighbor trendy boutiques.

Jacksonville Zoo and Gardens - Face-to-Face with Big Cats: This acclaimed facility features one of the most impressive tiger habitats in the Southeast, allowing visitors remarkable proximity to these magnificent cats.
Bluff Park — views of the Mississippi
Oak Alley Plantation — exhibitions on slavery and the site
Journey Memphis → Jackson (I-55 South)
Old Capitol Museum (Jackson)

Lake Michigan dunes - largest on western shore

activities.text: St. Johns River Water Taxi - See the City from the Water: Cruise between attractions while enjoying panoramic views of Jacksonville's skyline reflecting off the river that defines the city.

Jacksonville Beaches - 30 Minutes to Paradise: Neptune Beach, Atlantic Beach, and Jacksonville Beach offer distinct personalities along miles of Atlantic shoreline, from family-friendly to surf-focused.
Portion of the Natchez Trace Parkway — scenic route

visits.text: Walk along Jekyll Island's ethereal Driftwood Beach, a surreal landscape where sun-bleached trees twisted into sculptural forms rise from golden sands. The entire island operates as a state park, ensuring conservation and wildlife protection across 5,700 acres of beaches, marshes, and maritime forests. This otherworldly scenery has attracted filmmakers, featuring in major productions including X-Men and The Walking Dead.

Explore the historic Millionaires' Village where Vanderbilts, Rockefellers, and Pulitzers once gathered in elegant 'cottages' that defined Gilded Age opulence. The Georgia Sea Turtle Center rescues and rehabilitates injured sea turtles, offering close encounters with these ancient mariners and their inspiring recovery stories. Passionate guides explain each turtle's journey from injury through rehabilitation.

activities.text: Cycle the scenic island loop past serene marshes, under canopies of moss-draped oaks, and along beaches where dolphins frequently surface offshore. Picnic on windswept dunes while spotting wildlife including deer, alligators, and countless shorebirds in this carefully preserved coastal sanctuary.

days_plan.itin_title: California's Epic Landscapes Road Trip: From Yosemite's Granite to Death Valley's Desert
California's Epic Landscapes Road Trip: From Yosemite's Granite to Death Valley's Desert

visits.text: Julian - A Gold Rush Town Famous for Apples: This entire mountain town is a California Historical Landmark, its 1870s gold mining heritage preserved in wooden storefronts and false-front buildings. Unexpectedly, the high altitude creates perfect apple-growing conditions.

Julian Pioneer Museum - Gold Rush to Apple Orchards: This small museum traces the town's evolution from mining camp to apple capital, displaying gold mining equipment alongside Victorian-era artifacts.

Apple Orchards and Cider Mills - Taste Julian's Famous Fruit: Numerous u-pick orchards and farm stands offer the chance to select your own apples from dozens of heirloom varieties, while cider mills press the fresh juice.

activities.text: Julian Apple Pie - The Town's Claim to Fame: Multiple bakeries compete for the title of best apple pie, each guarding their recipes jealously. Warm slices with cinnamon ice cream fuel heated debates about which reigns supreme.

Eagle and High Peak Mine Tour - Descend into Julian's Golden Past: This 1,000-foot tunnel tour reveals the hard-rock mining techniques that drew prospectors to these mountains, with gold veins still visible in the walls.

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate California Road Trip: From Redwood Forests to Desert Valley Depths

visits.text: Hawaii Volcanoes National Park — Witness ongoing volcanic activity at Kilauea, one of the world's most active volcanoes. The 1,348-square-kilometer park encompasses the summit caldera, lava tubes, steam vents, and barren lava fields from recent eruptions.

Thurston Lava Tube — Walk through this 150-meter tunnel formed 500 years ago when lava drained leaving a hollow tube. Ferns and native plants surround the entrance while the interior reveals smooth walls created by flowing molten rock.

Chain of Craters Road — Drive 30 kilometers descending from summit to sea across vast lava fields. The scenic route passes extinct craters, petroglyphs, and the Holei Sea Arch where lava enters the ocean creating new land.

Jaggar Museum Overlook — View the Kilauea caldera from the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory perched on the crater rim. When active, the lava lake glows orange against night skies while sulfur dioxide plumes rise from the summit.

Mauna Kea Summit — Ascend to 4,207 meters atop Hawaii's tallest mountain for sunset and stargazing from the world's premier astronomical observation site. Thirteen international telescopes crown the dormant volcano rising 10,200 meters from seafloor to summit.

Akaka Falls State Park — Hike the 0.6-kilometer loop trail through bamboo groves and rainforest to viewpoints of 135-meter Akaka Falls. The free-falling plunge pool empties into a lush gorge while 30-meter Kahuna Falls cascades nearby.

Rainbow Falls — Photograph this 24-meter waterfall best viewed in morning light when rainbows form in the mist. Located in Hilo, the cascade plunges over a lava cave where legend says Hawaiian goddess Hina lives.

Puuhonua o Honaunau National Historical Park — Explore this reconstructed Hawaiian place of refuge where kapu breakers and defeated warriors found sanctuary. The 73-hectare park preserves royal grounds, fishponds, and the Great Wall built around 1550.

activities.text: Black sand beach at Punaluu — Walk across volcanic sand formed by lava shattering on contact with cold ocean water. Endangered green sea turtles bask on the black beach beneath coconut palms in this remote South Point location.

Kona coffee farm tour — Learn how 100% Kona coffee grows on the volcanic slopes of Hualalai and Mauna Loa. Family farms offer tours explaining cultivation, harvesting, and roasting of this premium Hawaiian coffee variety.

Historic Kailua-Kona waterfront — Stroll past Hulihe'e Palace and Mokuaikaua Church, Hawaii's oldest Christian church built in 1820. The oceanfront village served as King Kamehameha I's royal compound from 1812 until his 1819 death.

Manta ray night snorkel — Swim with graceful manta rays attracted to plankton illuminated by underwater lights off Kona coast. The 4-meter wingspan giants glide inches from snorkelers in an unforgettable marine encounter.

Green sand beach hike — Trek 4.8 kilometers to Papakolea Beach, one of only four green sand beaches worldwide. Olivine crystals eroding from the cinder cone create the distinctive olive-colored sand accessible only by foot.

Fresh poke bowl dinner — Sample cubed raw fish marinated in soy sauce, sesame oil, and limu seaweed at local markets or restaurants. This Hawaiian staple showcases the islands' Pacific Rim culinary influences.

visits.text: Kansas City, Kansas - Where Sports Passion Runs Deep: This side of the metro area delivers world-class sporting experiences, from the roaring crowds at Children's Mercy Park to the thunder of engines at Kansas Speedway.

Children's Mercy Park - One of Soccer's Most Intimidating Venues: Home to Sporting KC, this canopy-roofed stadium has been voted among Major League Soccer's most hostile environments for visiting teams, thanks to the passionate fans who fill its 18,467 seats.

Kansas Speedway - Feel the NASCAR Thunder: This 1.5-mile tri-oval hosts major NASCAR events throughout the year, with the NASCAR Racing Experience allowing visitors to actually drive the track themselves.

Legends Field - Home of the Kansas City Monarchs: Named in honor of the legendary Negro Leagues team that dominated baseball for decades, this stadium hosts the American Association affiliate that continues the proud tradition.

activities.text: NASCAR Racing Experience - Drive the Oval Yourself: Adrenaline seekers can get behind the wheel of a real stock car and experience the thrill of speeds over 150 mph on the same track where champions compete.

days_plan.itin_title: Kansas Prairie Odyssey: Tallgrass Seas, Cowtowns & Western Legends

visits.text: Marvel at Kasha-Katuwe Tent Rocks National Monument, where remarkable cone-shaped formations created by volcanic eruptions six to seven million years ago rise dramatically from the canyon floor. The volcanic activity left pumice, ash, and tuff deposits exceeding 1,000 feet thick that have eroded into these extraordinary pointed spires. Located within Cochiti Pueblo lands, the monument protects both geological wonders and cultural heritage.

Hike the slot canyon trail winding between towering tent rock formations, ascending to panoramic viewpoints overlooking the entire monument and surrounding mesas. The narrow passages and dramatic rock walls create an otherworldly hiking experience unlike anywhere else in New Mexico. The varied layers of volcanic deposits reveal millions of years of geological history in their colorful striations.

activities.text: Experience the Rio Grande between Taos and Española, where excellent white-water rafting opportunities attract adventure seekers to challenging rapids cutting through volcanic gorges. Multiple outfitters along the river offer guided trips suitable for various skill levels and thrill preferences. The section south of Albuquerque toward Socorro provides calmer waters ideal for peaceful floating and kayaking.

days_plan.itin_title: The Grand Circle Road Trip: Utah & Arizona's National Parks Ultimate Guide

visits.text: Key Largo - The Diving Capital of the World: The first of the Florida Keys greets visitors with warm, clear water and pristine coral reefs that have made this the premier diving destination in North America.

John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park - America's First Underwater Park: This 70-nautical-square-mile marine sanctuary protects the only living coral reef in the continental United States, with snorkeling and diving tours departing daily to technicolor underwater wonderlands.

Christ of the Abyss - An Underwater Shrine: This nine-foot bronze statue rests in 25 feet of water at Key Largo Dry Rocks, a beloved destination for snorkelers and divers seeking a unique spiritual experience.
Stroll through Dagny Johnson Key Largo Hammock Botanical State Park, subtropical reserve of forests and coastal trails.
Discovery of Cannon Beach and Far Beach in John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park.

activities.text: Snorkeling and Scuba Diving - Explore the Only Living Coral Reef in the Continental USA: Daily boat tours transport visitors to shallow reefs teeming with tropical fish, sea turtles, and kaleidoscopic coral formations.
Glass-Bottom Boat Tours - Reef Views Without Getting Wet: For those who prefer to stay dry, glass-bottom vessels reveal the underwater world through clear viewing panels.
Snorkeling trip to observe Christ of the Abyss, iconic submerged statue of the Key Largo reef.

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate Florida Keys Road Trip: From Miami to Key West
Florida Keys Overseas Highway: Miami to Key West Road Trip

visits.text: Everglades National Park — Explore 1.5 million acres of sawgrass marshes, mangrove forests, and hardwood hammocks protecting unique subtropical wilderness. The Anhinga Trail offers close encounters with alligators, herons, and endangered species found nowhere else on Earth.

Seven Mile Bridge — Drive this engineering marvel spanning 11 kilometers across open ocean, connecting the Middle and Lower Florida Keys. Built in 1982 beside the original 1912 railroad bridge, it offers panoramic views of turquoise waters and distant islands.

Bahia Honda State Park — Swim in calm, clear waters at this pristine beach featuring fine white sand and shallow turquoise lagoons. The old railroad bridge remnants create a dramatic backdrop for one of Florida's most beautiful natural beaches.

Key West Lighthouse — Climb 88 steps up this 1848 brick lighthouse for panoramic views across the island and surrounding waters. The keeper's quarters museum displays maritime artifacts and chronicles the lighthouse's role in guiding ships through treacherous reefs.

Ernest Hemingway Home and Museum — Tour the 1851 Spanish Colonial house where Hemingway wrote For Whom the Bell Tolls and A Farewell to Arms. Descendants of his six-toed cats roam the lush gardens and rooms preserved with original furnishings.

Fort Zachary Taylor Historic State Park — Explore this 1845 coastal fortress that played crucial roles in the Civil War and Spanish-American War. The best-preserved Civil War fort in Florida features brick bastions and the state's finest natural beach.

Key West Butterfly and Nature Conservatory — Wander through a climate-controlled habitat housing 50-60 butterfly species from five continents. The glass-domed conservatory maintains tropical conditions for these delicate creatures among flowering plants and cascading waterfalls.

Duval Street — Stroll the historic mile-long boulevard connecting the Atlantic Ocean to the Gulf of Mexico. Colorful Conch houses, bars, galleries, and restaurants create the vibrant atmosphere that attracted artists and writers for generations.

Key West - The Southernmost Point in the Continental USA: This legendary island 90 miles from Cuba has attracted pirates, wreckers, artists, and eccentrics for centuries, creating a culture unlike anywhere else in America.
Duval Street - More Than 40 Bars in One Mile: This legendary strip stretching from Gulf to Atlantic hosts Key West's famous nightlife, from Sloppy Joe's to the Green Parrot.

Ernest Hemingway Home and Museum - Where the Master Wrote: Tour the Spanish Colonial house where Hemingway lived throughout the 1930s, penning classics while surrounded by his famous six-toed cats whose descendants still roam the property.

Fort Zachary Taylor Historic State Park - Civil War History and Key West's Best Beach: This star-shaped fortress built between 1845 and 1866 sits atop the island's finest swimming beach, combining history with crystal-clear water.
Southernmost Point Buoy - The Obligatory Photo Op: The colorful marker at the corner of South and Whitehead Streets marks 90 miles to Cuba and attracts lines of photographers throughout the day.
Crossing the iconic Seven Mile Bridge connecting Marathon to the Lower Keys.
Viewing Coco Plum and Sombrero Beach, among the most beautiful beaches in the Keys.
Discovery of Bahia Honda State Park and Calusa Beach.
Observing the Key deer at the National Key Deer Refuge in Big Pine Key.
Walking or biking to explore Key West, the southernmost point of the United States.
Photo at the Southernmost Point and Mile Marker 0.
Visit to the Turtle Museum and discovery of other museums according to interests.
Relaxation and swimming at Fort Zachary Taylor State Park.
Excursion in the Key West backcountry islands, including Boca Grande and dolphin watching.
Discovery of a local art gallery and tasting of a slice of Key Lime pie.

activities.text: Airboat tour in Everglades — Skim across shallow waters on a high-speed airboat spotting alligators, turtles, and wading birds. Guides explain the River of Grass ecosystem while navigating through sawgrass prairie and cypress swamps.

Overseas Highway scenic drive — Cruise along US Route 1 island-hopping through the Florida Keys with ocean views on both sides. The 182-kilometer journey passes 42 bridges connecting tropical isles fringed with coral reefs and mangroves.

Sunset at Mallory Square — Join the nightly celebration as street performers, artists, and food vendors gather to watch the sun sink into the Gulf of Mexico. The tradition draws crowds to this Key West waterfront since the 1960s.

Snorkeling at Dry Tortugas — Take a seaplane or ferry to this remote national park 110 kilometers west featuring pristine coral reefs and Fort Jefferson, America's largest coastal fort. Crystal-clear waters reveal tropical fish, sea turtles, and shipwrecks.

Fresh seafood lunch — Savor stone crab claws, conch fritters, and key lime pie at waterfront restaurants serving Gulf catches. Local specialties showcase Caribbean and Southern influences in casual tropical settings.

Southernmost Point photo — Visit the iconic buoy-shaped monument marking the continental USA's southernmost point, just 145 kilometers from Cuba. The colorful concrete marker attracts visitors seeking the symbolic endpoint of US Highway 1.
Mallory Square Sunset Celebration - A Nightly Festival: Street performers, artists, psychics, and food vendors gather each evening to celebrate Key West's legendary sunsets over the Gulf of Mexico.
Key West Sunset Cruises - Watch Day Turn to Night from the Water: Sail catamarans, schooners, and party boats offer front-row seats to the sunset spectacle.
Smathers Beach - Key West's Longest Stretch of Sand: This half-mile beach on the Atlantic side offers calm water, paddleboard rentals, and fewer crowds than downtown.
Boat trip to Gilligan's Island or the sandbanks of Marathon.
Sunset cruise around Key West.
Drive back to Miami or transfer to Key West airport.

visits.text: Experience the pristine natural beauty of Kiawah Island, where endless stretches of soft sand meet towering dunes and lush maritime forests untouched by commercial development. Sunlight filters through ancient trees in the most captivating ways, while deer, herons, and dolphins appear regularly throughout the landscape. This barrier island represents coastal South Carolina at its most refined.

Cycle along miles of shaded pathways winding through forests, past lagoons filled with wildlife, and directly onto beaches where firm sand allows extended rides along the shore. The island's world-famous golf courses, including the Ocean Course with its dramatic oceanfront holes, attract players from around the globe seeking championship-caliber challenges amid stunning scenery.

activities.text: Paddle through Kiawah's salt marshes at sunset when the landscape transforms into golden hues reflected across calm waters. Beach days reveal why this island consistently ranks among America's finest, with uncrowded shores and crystal-clear waters. The quiet luxury and naturally wild character create an atmosphere of peaceful exclusivity.

Blue Ridge to Tennessee — Scenic return via Watauga and Nolichucky valleys; optional stop at Andrew Johnson NHS in Greeneville for Reconstruction‑era history.

visits.text: Atchafalaya Basin — Boat through America's largest river swamp covering 3,600 square kilometers of cypress-tupelo forest and wetlands. Alligators, egrets, and herons inhabit this vast floodplain vital to Gulf of Mexico ecology and Cajun culture.

Vermilionville — Step into this 23-acre living history museum recreating an 1765-1890 Acadian, Creole, and Native American village. Costumed interpreters demonstrate traditional crafts, music, and foodways in restored Cajun homes along Bayou Vermilion.

Acadian Village — Explore this outdoor museum featuring 19th-century Cajun buildings relocated to create an authentic 1800s settlement. The 10-acre complex includes chapel, general store, and homes furnished with period antiques.

Cathedral of St. John the Evangelist — Admire this 1916 Dutch Romanesque Revival cathedral with twin 54-meter spires dominating Lafayette's skyline. The interior features rare Bavarian stained glass and a massive 1,200-pipe organ.
Journey to Lafayette, heart of Cajun country.
Walk around Cypress Lake to observe local wildlife.

activities.text: Zydeco dance hall — Experience authentic Cajun music and culture at local dance halls where accordion-driven zydeco draws dancers of all ages. The African American Creole music tradition blends blues, R&B, and French Louisiana melodies.

Cajun cuisine dinner — Feast on crawfish étouffée, gumbo, jambalaya, and blackened catfish at family restaurants preserving generations-old recipes. Lafayette's culinary scene celebrates French Acadian heritage with bold spices and fresh Gulf seafood.

Downtown Lafayette stroll — Browse the Jefferson Street district featuring local art galleries, boutiques, and cafes. The revitalized downtown celebrates Cajun and Creole culture through public art and architectural preservation.
Last dinner at a Creole restaurant before returning.
Guided boat tour in natural habitat

visits.text: Laguna Beach - Where Art Colony Meets Surf Colony: This Orange County gem has nurtured artists since the early 1900s, with over 100 galleries showcasing works from impressionism to cutting-edge contemporary. World-class waves break just steps away.

Laguna Beach Public Art - Open-Air Museum: The city maintains an impressive collection of outdoor sculptures and murals, from abstract installations on downtown corners to the famous 'Greeter' sculpture welcoming visitors since 1970.

Crystal Cove State Park - 3.2 Miles of Pristine Coastline: This protected stretch preserves undeveloped beachfront between Newport and Laguna, with the charming Historic District of 1930s beach cottages tucked into the bluffs.

Thousand Steps Beach - Worth Every Step: Despite the exaggerated name (it's actually about 230 steps), this steep descent rewards beachgoers with tide pools, sea caves, and some of the finest sand in Orange County.

activities.text: Pageant of the Masters - Living Art Like Nowhere Else: Each summer, this unique festival presents 'living pictures' - real people recreating famous artworks in elaborate tableaux that must be seen to be believed.

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate California Road Trip: From Redwood Forests to Desert Valley Depths

visits.text: Haleakala National Park — Sunrise — Ascend to the 3,055-meter summit of this dormant volcano for spectacular sunrise above the clouds. The massive crater spanning 11.2 kilometers houses cinder cones and endemic silversword plants in an otherworldly landscape.

Road to Hana — Navigate 103 kilometers of winding coastal highway featuring 600 curves and 59 bridges through lush rainforest. Waterfalls, black sand beaches, and dramatic ocean views make this one of the world's most scenic drives.

Wailua Falls — Photograph this twin waterfall plunging 24 meters into a tropical pool accessible directly from the road. The cascade appeared in Fantasy Island's opening credits and flows year-round through rainforest vegetation.

Molokini Crater — Snorkel or dive this crescent-shaped volcanic caldera rising from the ocean floor creating a natural aquarium. The partially submerged crater hosts 250 fish species and 38 coral types in crystal-clear waters with 45-meter visibility.

Lahaina Historic District — Explore this former whaling village and Hawaiian royal capital featuring 19th-century buildings and the massive Banyan Tree planted in 1873. The National Historic Landmark preserves missionary homes, the old courthouse, and prison.

Iao Valley State Monument — Hike to viewpoints of the 370-meter Iao Needle, a lava remnant sacred to Hawaiians as Kuka'emoku. The verdant valley receives abundant rainfall creating lush tropical vegetation and was the site of Kamehameha's 1790 battle.

Front Street Lahaina — Browse art galleries, jewelry shops, and restaurants in this oceanfront historic district. The walkable street features whale bones, ship anchors, and maritime heritage from Lahaina's whaling era.

activities.text: Black sand beach at Waianapanapa — Walk across volcanic black pebbles formed by lava meeting ocean creating dramatic contrast against turquoise waters. The state park features lava tubes, sea caves, and ancient Hawaiian burial sites.

Bamboo forest hiking — Trek through dense bamboo groves along the Pipiwai Trail to 122-meter Waimoku Falls. The 6.4-kilometer roundtrip passes banyan trees and traverses boardwalks through magical bamboo cathedral.

Fresh fish plate lunch — Sample ahi poke, loco moco, or teriyaki chicken with rice and macaroni salad at roadside stands. Plate lunch represents Hawaii's multicultural fusion cuisine in generous portions.

Whale watching cruise — Spot humpback whales migrating to Hawaiian waters December through April to mate and calve. The 18-meter mammals breach, tail slap, and sing in the warm Pacific, with up to 10,000 visiting annually.

Sunset dinner cruise — Sail along Maui's west coast enjoying Hawaiian music, tropical cocktails, and buffet dinner as the sun sinks into the Pacific. Catamaran cruises offer romantic evening experiences with whale sightings in season.

days_plan.itin_title: Hawaii Island Paradise: Volcanoes, Waterfalls & Turquoise Seas
Hawaii Island Paradise: Volcanoes, Waterfalls & Turquoise Seas

visits.text: Discover Lake Allatoona, a sprawling 12,000-acre reservoir surrounded by forested hills and scenic shoreline offering excellent opportunities for swimming, boating, and lakeside relaxation. The clear waters and numerous sandy beaches make this destination perfect for families seeking outdoor recreation combined with natural beauty. Multiple marinas provide boat rentals for exploring hidden coves and peaceful inlets.

Explore the historic Allatoona Pass Battlefield, where dramatic red clay cliffs and a remarkable 175-foot-deep railroad cut tell the story of fierce Civil War combat. The strategic gorge and sweeping views over the lake create a striking landscape where history and natural beauty converge. Walking trails connect key battlefield sites with panoramic overlooks.

activities.text: Hike the Pine Mountain Trail Loop for elevated perspectives over the shimmering lake waters, then camp under starlit skies at Red Top Mountain State Park. The area offers diverse recreational options from fishing and paddleboarding to scenic picnic areas along the forested shoreline.

visits.text: Lake Ouachita - Arkansas's Crystal-Clear Inland Sea: Spanning 40,000 acres with over 970 miles of pristine shoreline, this reservoir consistently ranks among America's cleanest lakes. Created by Blakely Mountain Dam, its impossibly clear waters reveal depths up to 40 feet, nestled among the forested Ouachita Mountains.

Garvan Woodland Gardens - 210 Acres of Botanical Paradise: Rising from a peninsula on Lake Hamilton, this University of Arkansas botanical garden transforms Ouachita forest into themed displays featuring the stunning Anthony Chapel, Asian garden, and America's largest bridge of its kind-all reflected in tranquil waters.

activities.text: Lake Ouachita Water Sports - Dive into Pure Mountain Water: The exceptional clarity supports world-class scuba diving revealing underwater rock formations, while kayakers, sailors, and anglers explore endless secluded coves surrounded by national forest.

Three Sisters Springs - Secret Turquoise Pools: Accessible only by boat, these natural springs create otherworldly blue pools where cold groundwater meets the lake, drawing snorkelers to their ethereal depths.

days_plan.itin_title: Arkansas Itinerary: Hot Springs, Ozarks and Natural Parks

visits.text: Emerald Bay State Park viewpoints and Tahoe Rim Trail segment.

Lake Tahoe - America's Most Stunning Alpine Lake: Straddling California and Nevada at 6,225 feet elevation, this cobalt-blue jewel holds enough water to cover all of California 14 inches deep. The lake's legendary clarity allows visibility to depths of 70 feet, revealing a world of sapphire and emerald.

Emerald Bay State Park - The Crown Jewel of Tahoe's Shoreline: This pristine bay, accessible only by boat or trail, cradles tiny Fannette Island, Tahoe's only island. The Scandinavian-style Vikingsholm castle, built in 1929, represents one of the finest examples of Scandinavian architecture in North America.

Sand Harbor - Where Sierra Granite Meets Crystal Waters: Massive boulders emerge from impossibly clear water in compositions that seem designed by nature's finest artist. The summer Shakespeare festival stages performances against this breathtaking natural backdrop.

Lake Tahoe — Marvel at North America's largest alpine lake spanning 496 square kilometers at 1,897 meters elevation. The impossibly blue waters reach 501 meters deep surrounded by Sierra Nevada peaks straddling the California-Nevada border.

Emerald Bay State Park — Photograph this fjord-like inlet featuring Fannette Island, Lake Tahoe's only island, topped by a stone teahouse. The scenic overlook offers the lake's most iconic vista with crystal waters framed by granite cliffs.

Sand Harbor — Swim in the clearest waters along massive granite boulders creating natural sculptures. This Nevada State Park beach offers white sand and turquoise waters rivaling tropical destinations.

Vikingsholm Castle — Tour this 1929 Scandinavian-style mansion built as summer retreat, considered finest example of Scandinavian architecture in the Western Hemisphere. The 38-room castle required 200 workers to construct on Emerald Bay's shores.

activities.text: Tahoe Rim Trail - 165 Miles Circling Paradise: This long-distance trail offers everything from easy day hikes to multi-week expeditions, with panoramic lake views from forested ridges and wildflower meadows.

Winter Sports Capital of California: World-class ski resorts including Palisades Tahoe (formerly Squaw Valley, host of the 1960 Winter Olympics) offer some of the finest powder in North America, with season lengths rivaling Colorado.
Lake Tahoe Scenic Drive — Navigate 116 kilometers around the lake passing beaches, vista points, and forest. The route offers constantly changing mountain and water views.
Kayaking on crystal waters — Paddle across transparent waters allowing visibility to 21 meters depth. The lake's purity and dramatic shoreline create unforgettable paddling experiences.
Lakeside dining — Savor fresh trout and steaks at restaurants overlooking the sapphire waters. Tahoe's culinary scene emphasizes mountain cuisine with stunning views.

visits.text: Stand at the Caesars Head overlook for endless views of Blue Ridge Mountain ridgelines and valleys stretching to the horizon. This dramatic granite outcrop provides some of the most spectacular mountain scenery in the entire state. The crisp mountain air and panoramic vistas make this a must-visit destination for nature lovers seeking awe-inspiring landscapes.

Hike to Raven Cliff Falls, the tallest waterfall in South Carolina, cascading dramatically over a 420-foot cliff. The approximately five-mile round-trip trail rewards hikers with one of the most impressive natural sights in the region. A suspension bridge on the Dismal Trail loop provides close-up views of the falls that few visitors forget.

activities.text: Squeeze through Devil's Kitchen, a quirky narrow rocky passageway leading toward the overlook that adds adventure to the mountain experience. The rugged trails, peaceful forests, and dramatic rock formations of Caesars Head State Park showcase the Blue Ridge at its finest. This mountain destination reminds visitors why escaping to the highlands feels so rejuvenating.

Explore Landrum's charming downtown, where rolling foothills, sweeping mountain views, and country roads lined with farms create an idyllic setting. Visit Pearson's Falls, a beautiful 90-foot waterfall tucked into a lush nature preserve, and hike the Blue Wall Preserve for stunning mountain panoramas. The area's equestrian culture adds distinctive character to this hidden gem.

days_plan.itin_title: South Carolina Grand Tour: Charleston to Blue Ridge Mountains

visits.text: Las Vegas Springs Preserve — Desert ecology galleries and trails on the city’s historic water source; ideal orientation to Mojave flora and heat safety.
Return to Las Vegas via Cima Dome Joshua tree woodland; observe recovery areas from recent wildfires and avoid off‑road travel.

Las Vegas Strip — Walk the 6.8-kilometer boulevard lined with mega-resorts recreating world landmarks from the Eiffel Tower to Venetian canals. This entertainment capital features 30 casinos including Bellagio's fountains choreographed to music and the Luxor's 42.3-billion-candlepower sky beam.

Bellagio Conservatory and Botanical Gardens — Marvel at elaborate seasonal displays featuring thousands of flowers, trees, and sculptures. The 13,000-square-foot space transforms five times annually with themes created by 120 horticulturists.

Fremont Street Experience — Discover old Las Vegas under the Viva Vision canopy featuring 12.5 million LED lights creating 360-degree shows. The pedestrian mall in downtown's historic casino district offers vintage neon, street performers, and zip-lining.

Mob Museum — Explore organized crime and law enforcement history in the former 1933 federal courthouse. Interactive exhibits chronicle Las Vegas's mob connections, Prohibition, and the FBI's fight against organized crime.

Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area — Drive the 21-kilometer scenic loop through Mojave Desert landscapes featuring 900-meter red and tan Aztec sandstone cliffs. The 78,000-hectare area protects Joshua trees, desert tortoises, and rock climbing routes.

Calico Hills — Hike among swirling patterns in petrified sand dunes deposited 180 million years ago. The multicolored sandstone creates photographers' paradise with formations glowing brilliant orange and red.

Valley of Fire State Park — Explore Nevada's oldest and largest state park featuring 16,000 hectares of Aztec sandstone transformed red by iron oxide. The formations date to 150 million years ago when dinosaurs roamed shifting sand dunes.

Atlatl Rock — View prehistoric petroglyphs carved by Ancestral Puebloans and Paiute peoples on this sandstone outcrop. The rock art depicts atlatls—spear-throwing devices—along with bighorn sheep and geometric designs.

Great Basin National Park — Explore Nevada's only national park protecting 31,000 hectares from desert to 3,982-meter Wheeler Peak. The park encompasses bristlecone pine groves, Lehman Caves, and dark skies perfect for stargazing.
Lehman Caves — Tour marble caverns decorated with rare shield formations, stalactites, and helictites. The 90-minute guided walk reveals underground chambers carved by water over millions of years.
Bristlecone Pine Grove — Hike among Earth's oldest living organisms, some bristlecone pines exceeding 4,000 years. The gnarled trees survive harsh conditions at high elevation in the Snake Range.
Las Vegas Strip — Read the Strip’s layered urban design from neon marquees to mirrored towers; an engineered theater of light and spectacle.
Hoover Dam — Consider Art Deco motifs and interwar megaproject engineering at the Colorado River’s Black Canyon.
Las Vegas Strip: Charlie exploits Raymond's calculation abilities to count cards at blackjack and win enough to pay off his debts.

activities.text: Evening supply run and early lights‑out for pre‑dawn desert starts.
Departure buffer; optional Neon Museum or Downtown Arts District.

Cirque du Soleil show — Witness acrobatic artistry in one of seven permanent Cirque productions performing on the Strip. The Canadian entertainment company revolutionized Las Vegas shows with theatrical circus performances.
Casino buffet experience — Feast at legendary all-you-can-eat buffets offering cuisines from around the world. Las Vegas pioneered the buffet concept in 1946 to keep gamblers on property.

Fountains of Bellagio show — Watch choreographed water jets dance to classical music and contemporary hits. The 8-acre lake features over 1,200 nozzles shooting water up to 140 meters high in performances every 15-30 minutes.

Fire Wave hike — Trek 2.4 kilometers to this swirling sandstone formation resembling frozen waves of red and white rock. The moderate trail reveals one of Valley of Fire's most photographed geological wonders.
Desert wildlife watching — Spot desert bighorn sheep, chuckwallas, and desert tortoises adapted to extreme Mojave conditions. Early morning and late afternoon offer best viewing opportunities.
Loneliest Road drive — Navigate US Route 50 across Nevada's vast emptiness dubbed America's Loneliest Road. The 640-kilometer journey reveals basin and range geography under big skies.
Return to Las Vegas — Complete the Nevada loop returning to the neon oasis. The contrast between wilderness and civilization epitomizes Nevada's diverse character.
Night photography walk — Use railings and bridges as leading lines; carry water and avoid peak traffic.
Final calm exchanges on the train, where the coming physical distance no longer erases the bond between the two brothers.

visits.text: Lassen Volcanic National Park - The Only Place on Earth with All Four Volcano Types: Walk through a geothermal wonderland where the earth bubbles, hisses, and steams beneath your feet. This living laboratory showcases plug dome, shield, cinder cone, and composite volcanoes all within park boundaries.

Bumpass Hell - Three Miles into the Largest Hydrothermal Area in the Cascades: Follow the boardwalk trail past roaring fumaroles, bubbling mudpots, and scalding pools painted in otherworldly hues of orange, yellow, and turquoise. The trail honors Kendall Bumpass, who lost a leg when he broke through thin crust into boiling water.

Sulphur Works - Drive-Up Geothermal Theater: Steam vents and bubbling mud pools mere feet from the road offer the easiest access to the park's volcanic activity. The sulfurous smell announces your arrival before you see the first wisp of steam.

activities.text: Lassen Peak Summit Trail - Climb an Active Volcano: This 5-mile round-trip hike ascends 2,000 feet to the 10,457-foot summit, offering 360-degree views of the volcanic landscape. Lassen Peak last erupted in 1915, creating the devastated area still visible today.

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate California Road Trip: From Redwood Forests to Desert Valley Depths

visits.text: Lawrence - The City of Jayhawks: This energetic university town hums with youthful vitality both on and off the University of Kansas campus, blending world-class museums with a walkable downtown district.

KU Natural History Museum - Nationally Recognized Collections: Exhibits spanning dinosaurs, bugs, and mammals have earned this institution acclaim as one of the finest natural history museums in the Midwest.

Robert J. Dole Institute of Politics - Home of the World's Largest Stained-Glass American Flag: This museum gallery honors the Kansas senator's legacy through compelling exhibits on American political history.

Spencer Museum of Art - 45,000 Works Spanning Continents and Eras: One of the region's most comprehensive university art collections showcases pieces from ancient civilizations to contemporary masters.
Massachusetts Street - The Heart of Lawrence: This pedestrian-friendly boulevard buzzes with independent shops, galleries, and entertainment venues in beautifully preserved historic buildings.

Grinter's Sunflower Farm - 40 Acres of Golden Blooms: For over 50 years, this family farm near Lawrence has welcomed visitors to wander through fields of sunflowers during their late August peak, the quintessential Sunflower State experience.

activities.text: Clinton Lake - Clear Waters and Excellent Fishing: This 7,000-acre reservoir offers prime fishing for channel catfish and walleye, with a full-service marina providing 590 boat slips and rentals.

days_plan.itin_title: Kansas Prairie Odyssey: Tallgrass Seas, Cowtowns & Western Legends

visits.text: Deception Pass Bridge — Cross this dramatic 555-meter steel cantilever bridge connecting Whidbey Island to Fidalgo Island 55 meters above churning tidal waters. The 1935 structure frames views of rocky islands and forest-clad cliffs plunging to the sea.

Leavenworth Bavarian Village — Stroll this Alpine-themed town transformed in the 1960s with Bavarian architecture, beer gardens, and German restaurants. The former logging town reinvented itself as a tourist destination in the Cascade Mountains.

Waterfront Park — Walk along the Wenatchee River through this landscaped park featuring traditional German gazebos and gardens. The park hosts festivals year-round from Oktoberfest to Christmas lighting ceremonies.

Nutcracker Museum — View over 7,000 nutcrackers from around the world in this unique collection spanning six rooms. Examples range from medieval functional tools to ornate Bavarian figures and modern artistic interpretations.

activities.text: German cuisine sampling — Feast on schnitzel, bratwurst, spätzle, and apple strudel at authentic Bavarian restaurants complete with lederhosen-clad servers. Beer gardens serve German imports and local craft brews in festive atmosphere.

Icicle Gorge Trail hiking — Trek along the cascading Icicle Creek through old-growth forest and granite canyons. The relatively easy 4-mile trail offers swimming holes and dramatic mountain scenery in the Alpine Lakes Wilderness.

Wine tasting at local wineries — Sample Riesling, Chardonnay, and Pinot Noir at tasting rooms surrounding Leavenworth. The Cascade foothills' elevation and temperature variations create favorable growing conditions.

visits.text: Discover the Davidson County Historical Museum, housed in an elegant 19th-century Greek Revival building that provides an excellent opportunity to learn about Lexington's rich history and culture. The museum's fascinating exhibits chronicle the development of this charming Piedmont community through artifacts and historical displays.

Admire the stunning collection of works at the Bob Timberlake Gallery, celebrating one of North Carolina's most beloved artists. The gallery showcases Timberlake's masterful paintings capturing the essence of Southern rural life and the natural beauty of the Carolina landscape.

activities.text: Experience Lexington's lively winery scene, which offers plenty of opportunities to sample excellent local wines. The serene atmosphere at Childress Vineyards provides the perfect setting for tasting award-winning dry white wines while enjoying the beautiful rolling Piedmont countryside that surrounds this celebrated vineyard.

days_plan.itin_title: North Carolina Road Trip: From Outer Banks Beaches to Blue Ridge Mountains

visits.text: Liberal - Dorothy's Other Kansas Home: This southwestern Kansas town offers another immersive Wizard of Oz experience, competing with Wamego for fans of the beloved story.

Dorothy's House and the Land of Oz - Follow the Yellow Brick Road: Dorothy herself leads your whirlwind tour through this attraction, meeting the Scarecrow, Tin Man, and Cowardly Lion on the magical path to the Wizard.
Dorothy's Farmhouse - Where the Tornado Touched Down: Tour the recreated Kansas farmhouse, imagining the moment young Dorothy was swept away to the magical Land of Oz.
Oz Memorabilia Museum - Decades of Oz Collectibles: Browse extensive displays of Wizard of Oz merchandise, props, and artifacts spanning the beloved story's long history.

activities.text: Pancake Race - Liberal's Quirky Tradition: Each Shrove Tuesday, Liberal hosts an international pancake race, competing against Olney, England, in a tradition dating to 1950.

days_plan.itin_title: Kansas Prairie Odyssey: Tallgrass Seas, Cowtowns & Western Legends

visits.text: Lindsborg - More Swedish Than Sweden: Visitors from Scandinavia themselves say this Kansas town feels more authentically Swedish than modern Sweden, thanks to its traditional festivities and architecture.

Coronado Heights - A Castle Overlooking the Prairie: Climb this 300-foot-tall bluff crowned with a castle-like stone shelter for panoramic views across the Kansas landscape that Spanish conquistadors once traversed.

Wild Dala Horses - A Herd of Painted Wooden Creatures: The Swedish Dala horse tradition inspired these colorful sculptures scattered throughout Lindsborg, each painted with unique designs waiting to be discovered.
Hemslöjd Swedish Gift Shop - Take Home a Piece of Sweden: Browse traditional Swedish crafts, including personalized Dala-shaped house signs, at this authentic Scandinavian emporium.

activities.text: Swedish Heritage Walking Tour - Discover Little Sweden: Explore the architecture, shops, and traditions that have made this Kansas town a living tribute to Scandinavian culture.

days_plan.itin_title: Kansas Prairie Odyssey: Tallgrass Seas, Cowtowns & Western Legends

visits.text: Litchfield Hills - Connecticut's Most Pristine Countryside: Quiet country roads wind through this rural region where small towns seem lifted straight from a painting. The famous Litchfield town green exemplifies New England charm, surrounded by 18th-century homes and historic churches.

Lake Waramaug - A Glacial Jewel Shared by Three Towns: This idyllic lake stretches across Kent, Warren, and New Preston, its shores lined with forests, farms, and a state park offering swimming, hiking, and spectacular fall foliage viewing.

West Cornwall Covered Bridge - The Most Photographed Span in Connecticut: This beloved 1864 covered bridge carries traffic across the Housatonic River in a scene that defines New England's romantic appeal, especially when autumn colors reflect in the waters below.

activities.text: Housatonic River Paddling - Whitewater to Flatwater Adventures: The Housatonic offers paddling for all skill levels, from challenging rapids at Rattlesnake in Falls Village and Bull's Bridge in Kent to gentle flows through Cornwall's meadows and farms.

Eagle Landing State Park - Winter Wildlife Spectacle: Visit Haddam's riverside park where bald eagles congregate from December through March to nest and fish along the riverbank, one of New England's premier eagle-watching destinations.

Connecticut Wine Trail Northwest - Vineyard Hopping in the Hills: Several wineries dot the Litchfield Hills region, including Connecticut Valley Winery with award-winning varietals and Sharpe Hill Vineyard featuring a Zagat-rated restaurant amid rolling countryside.

days_plan.itin_title: Connecticut Coastal Drive: From Maritime Mystic to Ivy League New Haven

visits.text: Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site - Where Nine Teenagers Changed America Forever: Stand before the very doors where, in 1957, nine brave African-American students challenged segregation and altered the course of American history. Federal troops lined these steps as the world watched democracy tested. The preserved halls and powerful visitor center exhibits tell one of the Civil Rights Movement's most pivotal stories.

Clinton Presidential Library & Museum - Inside the Glass Bridge of American Politics: This striking cantilevered structure jutting over the Arkansas River houses a full-scale Oval Office replica and the largest archival collection of any U.S. presidency. Explore the defining moments of the 1990s through immersive exhibits spanning two terms that shaped modern America.

The Old Mill at T.R. Pugh Memorial Park - Hollywood's Secret Arkansas Star: This enchanting 1933 watermill gained immortality in the opening scene of 'Gone with the Wind.' Hidden among its rustic stones and cascading waters, observe the wildlife and fairy-tale landscapes that continue to draw photographers and filmmakers to this magical corner of Little Rock.
Little Rock: Thelma, a suffocated housewife, and Louise, a tired waitress, prepare a simple weekend car trip to escape their burdensome daily routine.
Roadside bar near Little Rock: Thelma is assaulted in the parking lot, Louise defends her and kills her attacker, turning their getaway into a flight from the law.

activities.text: Big Dam Bridge - Pedal Across America's Longest Purpose-Built Pedestrian Bridge: Spanning 4,226 feet across the Arkansas River, this engineering marvel connects 14 miles of scenic trails with sweeping views of the Little Rock skyline and surrounding mountains. Walk or cycle as the river flows beneath your feet.
Decision not to notify the police and to head southwest, convinced that justice will not protect them.

visits.text: Stand atop Lookout Mountain at Rock City Gardens, a remarkable natural park where ancient rock formations, lush gardens, and whimsical stone pathways lead to Lover's Leap overlook with views extending across seven states. The 180-foot suspension bridge provides exhilarating passage above forested ravines while cave grottos reveal fairytale scenes tucked into the mountain's mysterious recesses. Towering sandstone cliffs and carefully cultivated gardens create unforgettable vistas.

Descend into the mountain at Ruby Falls, where an underground pathway leads to a spectacular 145-foot waterfall cascading within an ancient limestone cavern. The illuminated cave formations and thundering waters create a subterranean spectacle unlike anything above ground. Guided tours reveal the geological history of this remarkable natural wonder.

activities.text: Visit the dramatically positioned Covenant College, whose Gothic Revival stone buildings rise castle-like from the clifftops with commanding views across Georgia, Tennessee, and Alabama. Sunset Rock offers photographers ideal conditions for capturing the Blue Ridge Mountains bathed in golden evening light.

days_plan.itin_title: Georgia's Grand Circle: Caucasus Mountains, Tbilisi & Black Sea Coast

visits.text: Visit the Los Alamos History Museum, which chronicles the town's remarkable transformation from a remote homesteading outpost to the epicenter of scientific research during World War II and the Cold War. The exhibits document how this isolated mesa became home to the Manhattan Project and changed the course of world history. Personal stories and artifacts illuminate the human dimension of this extraordinary chapter.

Explore the Bradbury Science Museum at Los Alamos National Laboratory, offering deeper insights into the development of atomic science and the Laboratory's ongoing research programs. Interactive exhibits explain complex scientific concepts while presenting the historical context of nuclear research. The museum provides a thoughtful examination of both the achievements and ethical considerations surrounding atomic energy.

activities.text: Discover Bandelier National Monument, protecting over 33,000 acres of ancestral Puebloan cliff dwellings, petroglyphs, and pristine mountain wilderness where the Rio Grande flows through dramatic canyons. The archaeological sites date back nearly 11,000 years, revealing how ancient peoples adapted to this challenging environment. Hiking trails lead to remarkable cave dwellings that visitors can climb into and explore.

Experience Valles Caldera National Preserve, an 89,000-acre protected area centered on a massive volcanic caldera formed approximately 1.25 million years ago. The vast grassland valley surrounded by forested mountain slopes creates landscapes of extraordinary beauty. Elk herds graze across the caldera floor, visible from scenic overlooks along the preserve's rim.

visits.text: Journey to Los Angeles and discovery of Santa Monica Pier
Visit to Getty Center
Hike to Griffith Observatory to see the Hollywood Sign
Stroll through Beverly Hills

Venice Beach Boardwalk — Immerse yourself in the electric atmosphere of this iconic promenade where Muscle Beach bodybuilders, eccentric street artists and tie-dye vendors create a permanent spectacle. Skaters defy gravity in the historic skate park.

Getty Center — Explore this museum complex perched on a Brentwood hill designed by Richard Meier and opened in 1997. The European paintings collection rivals Robert Irwin's gardens and panoramic views of glittering Los Angeles.

Hollywood Walk of Fame — Walk Hollywood Boulevard searching for the 2,700 terrazzo and brass stars honoring entertainment icons since 1960. The neighboring Chinese Theatre displays handprints and footprints of Hollywood legends.

Griffith Observatory — Admire the spectacular panorama of Los Angeles from this 1935 Art Deco building overlooking Hollywood. Free public telescopes allow observation of planets and stars while the planetarium projects immersive cosmic shows.

Los Angeles - The Entertainment Capital of the World: This sprawling metropolis of 4 million (13 million in the metro area) has shaped global culture through film, television, music, and art. From celebrity-studded Beverly Hills to artsy Silver Lake, each neighborhood has its own distinct identity.

Hollywood Walk of Fame - 2,700 Stars and Counting: This sidewalk tribute stretching 1.3 miles along Hollywood Boulevard has honored entertainment icons since 1960. The handprints and footprints at the TCL Chinese Theatre add another layer of celebrity worship.

Griffith Observatory - Where LA Meets the Cosmos: This Art Deco landmark on the slopes of Mount Hollywood offers free admission, planetarium shows, and the most iconic view of the Hollywood Sign. The observatory has appeared in countless films from Rebel Without a Cause to La La Land.

The Getty Center - A Hilltop Temple to Art: This billion-dollar campus designed by Richard Meier houses masterpieces spanning antiquity to the present, all with sweeping views from the Santa Monica Mountains to downtown. Admission is free; only parking costs.

Venice Beach Boardwalk - California's Counterculture Catwalk: Street performers, bodybuilders at Muscle Beach, muralists, fortune tellers, and every variety of California eccentric parade along this two-mile ocean-front circus.
In Los Angeles, Chris tries to resume a more normal life with work and housing, but quickly feels trapped and hits the road again.
Los Angeles: return to Charlie's life, meeting with Dr. Bruner and realization that money matters less than the rediscovered relationship with Raymond.
Los Angeles / Santa Ana station: Raymond returns to the institution, while Charlie promises to come see him again, finally accepting his brother as he is.
Santa Monica – last beach walk / morning coffee

activities.text: Walk on the Hollywood Walk of Fame
Visit to a movie studio

Brunch at Grand Central Market — Taste authentic tacos, steaming ramen and artisanal coffee in this historic 1917 food market in the heart of Downtown. The multicultural stalls reflect Los Angeles' culinary diversity in a preserved architectural setting.

Shopping on Rodeo Drive — Window shop along this luxurious Beverly Hills artery concentrating Chanel, Gucci and Prada in architectural statement boutiques. The glamorous atmosphere and majestic palm trees embody the Hollywood California dream.

Sunset at Santa Monica Pier — End your road trip on this century-old pier opened in 1909 with its solar Ferris wheel and 1922 carousel. The sun blazing over the Pacific while neon lights illuminate perfectly concludes the coastal adventure.

Santa Monica Pier - Where Route 66 Meets the Pacific: This iconic pier marks the official end of the Mother Road, featuring a solar-powered Ferris wheel, historic carousel, and views stretching to Malibu.

The Last Bookstore - A Cathedral of Literature: This downtown maze of tunnels, archways, and flying books occupies a former bank building, creating one of the world's most photographed independent bookstores.

The Broad - Contemporary Art for Everyone: This striking honeycomb-clad museum houses over 2,000 works of postwar and contemporary art, including Yayoi Kusama's famous Infinity Mirrored Room. Free tickets.
Vol prochaine étape
Final calm exchanges on the train, where the coming physical distance no longer erases the bond between the two brothers.

visits.text: Explore Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park, where massive earthen ceremonial mounds constructed over 1,000 years ago preserve evidence of sophisticated Native American civilization in the American Southeast. The reconstructed earth lodge contains an original clay floor where ancient councils gathered around a central fire pit. Museum exhibits display artifacts spanning 17,000 years of human habitation along the Ocmulgee River.

Discover Macon's rich musical heritage at the Tubman Museum, one of the largest museums in America dedicated to African American art, history, and culture. The city served as birthplace to music legends Little Richard and Otis Redding, whose influences still resonate through local venues and festivals. The Allman Brothers Band Museum preserves memorabilia from Southern rock's most influential group.

activities.text: Tour the opulent Hay House, a stunning Italian Renaissance Revival mansion featuring original 19th-century furnishings and technological innovations ahead of their time. The Grand Opera House, with its plush red velvet interior, hosts performances in a magnificently restored 1884 theater. Window-shop along Cherry Street's indie boutiques in the revitalized downtown district.

visits.text: Hammonasset Beach State Park - Connecticut's Largest Shoreline Park: This pristine 2-mile stretch of protected coastline draws beachgoers to sunbathe on sandy shores, swim in Long Island Sound's gentle surf, and stroll the historic boardwalk. The park's network of walking paths, fishing piers, and wildlife viewing areas remain open year-round.

Meigs Point Nature Center - Where Land Meets Sea: Located on the park's southern end, this facility features a turtle habitat and ten themed gardens showcasing native plant species. The surrounding wetlands and tidal pools provide excellent birdwatching opportunities.

Stroll through Madison's remarkably preserved antebellum district, where grand 19th-century mansions line oak-shaded streets virtually unchanged since the Civil War. Sherman's army famously spared this elegant town during the March to the Sea, preserving architectural treasures including Heritage Hall and the historic Rogers House. Manicured gardens, decorative fountains, and refined Southern storefronts create timeless elegance.

Visit Rose Cottage, built by Adeline Rose after she gained her freedom, offering moving insights into African American history in the antebellum South. The Steffen Thomas Museum showcases bold folk art in striking contrast to the town's refined classical architecture. Antique shops throughout the walkable historic district contain fascinating treasures from centuries past.

activities.text: Long Island Sound Sunset - Nature's Nightly Masterpiece: The park's western-facing shoreline offers spectacular sunset views across the sound, with colors reflecting off gentle waves as day turns to dusk.

Experience Madison's genteel Southern hospitality while exploring the town's carefully preserved heritage spanning two centuries of American history. The intimate scale and exceptional preservation make this one of Georgia's most photographically rewarding destinations for lovers of historic architecture.
