visits.text: Soak in the therapeutic hot springs of Truth or Consequences, a town whose unusual name dates to a 1950 radio quiz show promotion but whose healing waters have attracted visitors for centuries. The mineral-rich thermal pools scattered throughout the downtown area offer the least crowded and most affordable hot spring experiences in New Mexico. Multiple facilities provide options ranging from rustic to luxurious soaking environments.

Explore Elephant Butte Lake State Park north of town, New Mexico's largest reservoir offering excellent opportunities for hiking, biking, boating, and water sports. The lake's vast expanse and surrounding desert mountains create dramatic landscapes for outdoor recreation. The area serves as a convenient base for exploring the wild terrain of nearby Apache Kid Wilderness.

activities.text: Experience the Rio Grande riverside hot springs where thermal waters emerge directly beside the river, creating unique soaking opportunities that combine natural settings with healing mineral content. The town's relaxed atmosphere encourages extended stays focused on rest, relaxation, and rejuvenation. Local wellness practitioners complement the natural springs with massage and therapeutic services.

visits.text: Escape to Tybee Island, Savannah's laid-back beach retreat where wide sandy shores, rolling dunes, and tranquil marshlands create a carefree coastal atmosphere. The historic lighthouse, Georgia's oldest and tallest, has guided mariners since 1736 and offers panoramic views from its observation deck after climbing 178 steps. The island maintains nostalgic beach-town charm with colorful cottages and relaxed local culture.

Explore the imposing Fort Pulaski National Monument, a masterpiece of 19th-century military engineering whose massive brick walls were breached by rifled cannon during the Civil War, forever changing the course of warfare. The moated fortification and surrounding marshlands offer walking trails rich with birdlife and historical significance. Interpretive programs bring the fort's dramatic history to life.

activities.text: Swim and sunbathe at lively South Beach, spot dolphins offshore, and watch pelicans diving for fish as the sun sets over the Atlantic. The Tybee Pier and Pavilion area buzzes with activity while quieter stretches of shore provide peaceful escapes. Over 200 bird species make this island a rewarding destination for wildlife observation throughout the year.

visits.text: Jour 1: Worthington Glacier State Recreation Site - Located along Thompson Pass at 2,800 feet elevation, this glacier flows down from the Chugach Mountains to within easy viewing distance of the Richardson Highway. A paved trail leads to observation platforms, while more adventurous visitors can hike the two-mile Worthington Glacier Trail for closer access to the ice.

Jour 1: Bridal Veil Falls - This spectacular 900-foot cascade plunges down sheer cliffs along Keystone Canyon, visible from roadside pullouts and accessible via a mile-long trail to an overlook. The waterfall is most impressive during spring snowmelt and after summer rains.

Jour 1: Keystone Canyon - The Richardson Highway threads through this dramatic gorge carved by the Lowe River, with towering rock walls and multiple waterfalls creating one of Alaska's most scenic drives. Historic remnants of the failed Trans-Alaska Railway attempt are visible along the canyon walls.

Jour 2: Valdez Harbor and Waterfront - This ice-free port at the head of a fjord serves as the terminus of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline and a major fishing harbor. The downtown area rebuilt after the 1964 earthquake offers views of surrounding peaks rising directly from the water.

Jour 2: Prince William Sound - This island-studded waterway encompasses 15,000 square miles of protected waters, tidewater glaciers, and abundant marine wildlife. The sound's deep fjords and sheltered bays create ideal conditions for viewing sea otters, seals, sea lions, and whales.

activities.text: Jour 1: Thompson Pass Scenic Drive - The approach to Valdez crosses this 2,678-foot pass through the Chugach Mountains, an area receiving some of North America's highest snowfall totals. In summer, alpine meadows burst with wildflowers while glaciers cling to surrounding peaks.

Jour 2: Glacier Cruise - Day cruises venture into Columbia Bay to witness Columbia Glacier, one of Alaska's largest tidewater glaciers. These journeys navigate through floating icebergs while naturalists explain glacial geology and point out wildlife including puffins, kittiwakes, and marine mammals.

Jour 2: Sea Kayaking - Guided paddling excursions explore the fjords and bays surrounding Valdez, offering intimate access to marine ecosystems inaccessible by larger vessels. Multi-day expeditions reach remote glaciers and camping beaches.

Jour 2: Wildlife Viewing - Prince William Sound's nutrient-rich waters support abundant marine life, with sea otters, harbor seals, Steller sea lions, humpback whales, and orcas regularly observed. Seabird colonies host thousands of puffins, cormorants, and eagles.

visits.text: Virginia City — Step into this authentically preserved 1860s mining boomtown perched on Mount Davidson's slopes. The National Historic Landmark preserves boardwalks, Victorian buildings, and saloons from when Comstock Lode silver discovery created Nevada Territory.

The Way It Was Museum — Explore mining equipment, minerals, and artifacts explaining how the Comstock Lode produced 500 million dollars in silver and gold. The museum occupies the fourth floor of the 1876 Knights of Pythias building.

Chollar Mine — Descend into a real silver mine with original 1860s square-set timbering still supporting tunnels. Guided tours explain mining techniques that extracted precious metals from 300 meters underground.

St. Mary in the Mountains Catholic Church — Visit this 1876 Gothic Revival church built with mining wealth featuring Italian marble and stained glass. The cathedral replaced an earlier church destroyed in the Great Fire of 1875.

activities.text: C Street walking tour — Stroll the main street lined with saloons, shops, and museums occupying original 1860s buildings. Wooden boardwalks and Victorian storefronts recreate Wild West atmosphere.
Virginia & Truckee Railroad ride — Board vintage steam trains running the historic route built in 1869 to haul Comstock ore. The scenic journey passes mining ruins with mountain views.
Saloon experience — Sample local beers at authentic Old West saloons with swinging doors and antique bars. Some establishments maintain 1860s character serving spirits to modern visitors.

visits.text: Explore picturesque Waynesville, sandwiched between the Great Smoky Mountains and the Blue Ridge Mountains. This charming little town in Haywood County captivates visitors with sublime mountain views and a welcoming atmosphere that embodies the spirit of Southern Appalachian hospitality.

Catch an entertaining live performance at Haywood Arts Regional Theater, where talented local and regional artists showcase their skills. This celebrated venue brings cultural enrichment to the mountain community and offers visitors an authentic taste of Appalachian arts and entertainment.

activities.text: Experience downtown Waynesville's bustling atmosphere featuring an eclectic mix of galleries, antique shops, and local boutiques. Visit Haywood's Historic Farmers Market to meet hospitable locals, sample fresh farm produce, and discover unique heritage crafts that make perfect mementos of your mountain visit.

visits.text: Glacier National Park — Enter this 4,100-square-kilometer wilderness preserving pristine ecosystems from prairie to alpine peaks. The Crown of the Continent features 700 lakes, 25 active glaciers, and abundant wildlife including grizzlies, wolves, and mountain goats.

Going-to-the-Sun Road — Drive this engineering marvel crossing the Continental Divide at 2,026-meter Logan Pass. The 80-kilometer scenic road completed in 1932 hugs cliff faces with stunning glacier and valley views.

Lake McDonald — Photograph the park's largest lake stretching 16 kilometers with mountains reflected in pristine waters. The glacially-carved lake reaches 141 meters deep surrounded by old-growth cedar and hemlock forests.

Trail of the Cedars — Walk this wheelchair-accessible boardwalk through ancient rainforest featuring 500-year-old western red cedars. The 1.1-kilometer loop crosses Avalanche Creek on a suspension bridge.

Logan Pass — Hike from the Continental Divide summit where snow persists into July. The alpine visitor center offers exhibits and access to Hidden Lake Trail through wildflower meadows frequented by mountain goats.
Hidden Lake Overlook — Trek 4.8 kilometers roundtrip to dramatic views of turquoise Hidden Lake surrounded by peaks. The trail crosses alpine tundra revealing bighorn sheep and hoary marmots.
Jackson Glacier Overlook — View one of Glacier's most accessible glaciers from this roadside pullout. The ice field has receded significantly but remains impressive against the Continental Divide.
St. Mary Falls — Hike 2.6 kilometers through forest to this 10-meter waterfall cascading over bedrock. The trail follows Rose Creek through wildflower meadows with mountain views.

Lewis and Clark Caverns State Park — Tour Montana's largest known limestone cavern featuring stalactites, stalagmites, and helictites. The 90-minute guided walk descends into chambers carved by water over millions of years.
Gates of the Mountains — Boat through this section of the Missouri River where limestone cliffs rise 370 meters. Lewis and Clark named the formation in 1805 during their expedition upriver.
Helena historic downtown — Explore Montana's capital featuring Victorian architecture from gold rush prosperity. Last Chance Gulch preserves 1880s buildings housing shops and restaurants.
Going-to-the-Sun Road (partial if open) and Many Glacier area hikes.

activities.text: Wildlife watching — Scan meadows and roadside for grizzly bears, black bears, bighorn sheep, and mountain goats. Early morning and evening offer best viewing opportunities along Going-to-the-Sun Road.
Apgar Village exploration — Browse visitor center exhibits, rent boats, and dine at this lakeside village. The park's west entrance hub offers services and lake access.
Scenic boat tour — Cruise historic wooden boats across pristine lakes hearing park history and geology from naturalist guides. Tours operate on Lake McDonald and St. Mary Lake.
Evening ranger program — Attend talks about grizzly bears, glaciers, or night skies at park amphitheaters. Rangers share ecological knowledge and conservation challenges.
Huckleberry treats — Sample Montana's signature berry in ice cream, pie, or jam at park lodges. Wild huckleberries ripen in late summer throughout Glacier's forests.
Scenic drive return — Navigate mountain passes and valleys back to Glacier through heart of the Rockies. The journey showcases Montana's vast wilderness and big sky.
Farewell Montana dinner — Celebrate the journey with bison ribeye or grilled trout at a mountain lodge. Montana cuisine emphasizes wild game and locally raised meats.
Photography session at Swiftcurrent Lake.

visits.text: West Palm Beach - Florida's Emerging Cultural Capital: This rapidly developing city has cultivated world-class dining, entertainment venues, and high-end shopping while maintaining easy access to pristine Atlantic beaches.

Palm Beach - Billionaire's Row: Across the Intracoastal Waterway, Palm Beach proper showcases some of America's most valuable real estate, with beachfront mansions owned by the nation's wealthiest families.

John D. MacArthur Beach State Park - Preserved Paradise: This barrier island park protects one of the last remaining undeveloped stretches of the Palm Beach coast, with hiking trails, kayaking, and swimming on a pristine Atlantic beach.

Norton Museum of Art - World-Class Collection in the Tropics: This recently expanded museum houses significant European, American, and Chinese art collections in stunning galleries designed for natural light.

activities.text: Jupiter - Palm Beach's Best-Kept Secret: This small northern town offers outstanding beaches, historic lighthouse tours, and a laid-back atmosphere that contrasts with Palm Beach's formality.
Delray Beach and Boca Raton - Atlantic Avenue Strolling: These neighboring beach communities offer vibrant downtown districts filled with restaurants, boutiques, and galleries steps from the ocean.

days_plan.itin_title: The Ultimate Florida Keys Road Trip: From Miami to Key West

visits.text: Experience White Sands National Park, where the world's largest gypsum dune field creates a surreal landscape of brilliant white waves stretching across 275 square miles of the Tularosa Basin. The pristine white dunes, constantly shifting with the wind, provide an otherworldly environment unlike anywhere else on Earth. This rare ecosystem supports uniquely adapted plants and animals found nowhere else.

Walk the Interdune Boardwalk and Dune Life Nature Trail to discover how life persists in this seemingly barren landscape of pure white gypsum crystals. Interpretive signs explain the geological processes that created this remarkable feature and the adaptations that allow plants and animals to survive in such an extreme environment.

Experience White Sands National Park, where 275 square miles of brilliant white gypsum dunes create one of the most extraordinary landscapes on Earth. The crystalline sand formations shift constantly with the wind, creating an ever-changing terrain of pristine white waves rolling across the Tularosa Basin. This rare ecosystem supports uniquely adapted plants and animals found nowhere else, including species that have evolved white coloration to match their surroundings.

Hike the Interdune Boardwalk and Dune Life Nature Trail to discover how life persists in this seemingly barren landscape of pure white gypsum crystals. The trails reveal the surprising biodiversity hidden within the dune fields and explain the geological processes that created this natural wonder. The stark white landscape against deep blue desert skies creates unforgettable visual experiences.

activities.text: Sled down the pristine white dunes on specially designed sand discs available at the visitor center, creating unforgettable memories in one of the most photogenic landscapes in America. Sunset transforms the white sands into a canvas of pink, orange, and purple hues, offering photographers extraordinary opportunities for capturing the desert's ethereal beauty.

Sled down the pristine dunes using specially designed discs available at the visitor center, creating exhilarating descents through powdery white sand. Sunset transforms the white sands into a canvas of pink, orange, and purple hues, offering photographers extraordinary opportunities for capturing desert magic. Camping permits allow overnight stays for experiencing full moons and stargazing in one of America's darkest locations.

visits.text: Wichita - Kansas's Cultural and Culinary Capital: Five culturally rich museums line the Arkansas River, connected by a riverfront walkway that makes exploring this diverse city a pleasure.
Old Cowtown Museum - Wichita's Frontier Days Brought to Life: Costumed actors recapture the city's Wild West heritage in this living history museum, complete with period buildings and demonstrations.
Exploration Place - 10,000+ Works and 1950s Kansas in Miniature: Interactive exhibits include a miniature version of 1950s Kansas with more than 50 animations, bringing mid-century America to life.
Wichita Art Museum - American Art on the Arkansas: Over 10,000 works of American art fill this riverside institution, one of the largest art museums in the Great Plains.

Keeper of the Plains - 44 Feet of Iconic Sculpture: Local artist Blackbear Bosin's dramatic steel sculpture rises at the confluence of the Arkansas and Little Arkansas rivers, illuminated nightly by the Ring of Fire.

Mid-America All-Indian Museum - Native Heritage on Display: More works by Blackbear Bosin and extensive collections celebrating Native American art and culture await visitors to this riverside institution.

Botanica Wichita - 30+ Themed Gardens Open Year-Round: Sculptures, water features, 4,000 plant species, and a restored 1949 carousel accent this botanical garden that culminates annually with 2 million holiday lights.

activities.text: Arkansas River Walk - Connect Wichita's Cultural Treasures: Stroll, bike, or jog along the riverfront pathway linking museums, sculptures, and green spaces.

Bartlett Arboretum in Belle Plaine - A Prairie Rarity Flourishes: Thirty minutes south of Wichita, this century-old wooded haven hosts events beginning each April with Art at the Arb amid 40,000 tulips.

visits.text: Stroll along the historic Riverwalk in downtown Wilmington, a picturesque waterfront promenade stretching along the Cape Fear River. This charming walkway winds through the city's beautifully preserved historic district, offering stunning river views, unique shops, and glimpses of antebellum architecture. The Riverwalk perfectly captures the essence of Southern coastal charm.

activities.text: Explore Wilmington's historic downtown district, where centuries-old buildings house boutiques, galleries, and eateries along tree-lined streets. The city's rich maritime heritage and well-preserved architecture make it one of North Carolina's most photogenic destinations. Take time to admire the blend of antebellum mansions and waterfront charm that defines this coastal gem.

days_plan.itin_title: North Carolina Road Trip: From Outer Banks Beaches to Blue Ridge Mountains

visits.text: Wilson Lake - The Clearest Lake in Kansas: Red sandstone cliffs and pillars interrupt the shoreline of this remarkably clear reservoir, creating scenery more reminiscent of the Southwest than the Great Plains.

Wilson State Park - Where Smoky Hills Meet Crystal Waters: Lake lovers fish, paddle, boat, and swim while mountain bikers conquer the 25-mile Switchgrass Trail that snakes through canyons carved into the surrounding Smoky Hills.

activities.text: Switchgrass Trail - 25 Miles of Mountain Biking Adventure: This challenging trail system winds through Smoky Hills canyons, offering technical terrain and scenic views rarely associated with Kansas.

Cheney Lake Sailing - Kansas's Premier Wind Sports Destination: Steady prairie breezes have made this lake one of the nation's top sailing and windsurfing destinations, drawing a dedicated seafaring following.

days_plan.itin_title: Kansas Prairie Odyssey: Tallgrass Seas, Cowtowns & Western Legends

visits.text: New England Air Museum - The Largest Aviation Collection in the Northeast: Explore an extraordinary assemblage of aircraft, helicopters, engines, and memorabilia spanning the entire history of flight. Highlights include the oldest surviving aircraft in America (a hot air balloon basket) and the oldest Connecticut-constructed airplane.

Historic Aircraft Collection - From Pioneers to Jets: Walk among vintage fighters, bombers, and experimental aircraft in massive hangars, with knowledgeable volunteer docents-many former pilots and aviation professionals-ready to share stories behind each machine.

activities.text: Redbird Flight Simulator - Take the Controls: Experience the thrill of piloting through this realistic simulator, while younger visitors can build paper airplanes and participate in family-friendly aviation scavenger hunts throughout the facility.

days_plan.itin_title: Minnesota's Twin Cities: Minneapolis and St. Paul Lakes, Arts and Culture

visits.text: Columbia River Gorge — Cross this dramatic 1,200-meter-deep canyon where the Columbia River cuts through the Cascade Range. The 130-kilometer gorge creates the only sea-level route through the mountains, featuring over 77 waterfalls.

Multnomah Falls — Admire Oregon's tallest waterfall plunging 189 meters in two major tiers connected by the historic Benson Bridge built in 1914. The iconic cascade attracts over 2 million visitors annually to its easily accessible viewing platform.

Maryhill Museum of Art — Explore this eclectic collection housed in a 1914 mansion overlooking the Columbia River. Holdings include European paintings, Auguste Rodin sculptures, Native American artifacts, and Queen Marie of Romania's furnishings.

Yakima Valley wine country — Drive through Washington's premier wine region producing 40% of the state's grapes. The rain shadow of the Cascades creates ideal conditions for Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, and Chardonnay.

activities.text: Wine tasting tour — Visit family-owned wineries and tasting rooms sampling award-winning Washington wines. Many vineyards offer tours explaining viticulture practices and the valley's unique terroir.

Historic Highway 14 drive — Navigate this scenic route along the Columbia's north bank past basalt cliffs, orchards, and Native American fishing sites. The highway offers dramatic gorge views and access to small riverside communities.

Farm-to-table dinner — Savor cuisine featuring Yakima Valley produce including hops, apples, cherries, and wine. The agricultural region supplies ingredients to restaurants throughout the Pacific Northwest.

days_plan.itin_title: Washington State's I-90 Corridor: Seattle, Snoqualmie Pass & Alpine Lakes

visits.text: Explore York's traditional Southern town center, where the historic York County Courthouse and prominent commercial buildings line streets that retain their 19th-century character. As part of South Carolina's Olde English District, the town connects to important Revolutionary War history. The McCelvey Center, housed in a handsome brick building, serves as a Southern Revolutionary War Institute with exhibits and programs.

activities.text: Enjoy the outdoors at Anne Springs Close Greenway, an expansive natural area well-suited for quiet afternoon hikes, horseback riding, and nature observation. The greenway's trails wind through diverse habitats providing peaceful escapes from busier destinations. York's combination of history and natural beauty offers a fitting conclusion to a South Carolina journey.

days_plan.itin_title: South Carolina Grand Tour: Charleston to Blue Ridge Mountains

visits.text: Yosemite National Park - America's Cathedral of Stone and Water: Sheer granite walls rise 3,000 feet from the valley floor as waterfalls plunge from heights that dwarf skyscrapers. This UNESCO World Heritage Site inspired the conservation movement and continues to humble millions of annual visitors.

El Capitan - The World's Most Famous Big Wall: This 3,000-foot vertical granite monolith draws elite climbers from around the globe attempting multi-day ascents of routes like The Nose. Even from the valley floor, watching climbers as tiny specks on the face is mesmerizing.

Half Dome - Yosemite's Iconic Sentinel: This distinctive granite dome, cleaved as if by a giant's axe, rises 4,737 feet above the valley floor. The cables route to the summit remains one of America's most sought-after hiking achievements.

Yosemite Falls - North America's Tallest Waterfall: Water plunges 2,425 feet in three tiers, creating a spectacle visible from throughout Yosemite Valley. Peak flow occurs in May and June when snowmelt transforms the falls into a thundering curtain of white.

activities.text: Tunnel View - The Most Photographed Vista in America: This overlook presents El Capitan, Half Dome, and Bridalveil Fall in a single sweeping panorama that has graced countless postcards, calendars, and desktop backgrounds.

Glacier Point - Stand 3,214 Feet Above the Valley: This dramatic overlook provides bird's-eye views of Yosemite's greatest hits, with Half Dome at eye level and the High Sierra stretching to the horizon.
Mariposa Grove - Walk Among Giant Sequoias: Over 500 mature giant sequoias populate this ancient forest, including the 1,800-year-old Grizzly Giant with its 96-foot circumference.
